introduction.p:
For Problems 59-64,
Graph each function in the ZTrig window, and write a simpler expression for the function.
Show algebraically that your new expression is equivalent to the original one.

p.m: \begin{aligned}[t]\dfrac{\csc x}{\cot x} \amp=\dfrac{\dfrac{1}{\sin x}}{\dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x}}\\ \amp= \dfrac{1}{\sin x}\div \dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x} \\ \amp= \dfrac{1}{\sin x}\cdot \dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x} \\ \amp= \dfrac{1}{\cos x} \\ \amp= \sec x\end{aligned}
\dfrac{\sec x \cot x}{\csc x}=\dfrac{\dfrac{1}{\cos x} \cdot \dfrac{\cos x}{\sin x}}{\dfrac{1}{\sin x}} = \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{\sin x}}{\dfrac{1}{\sin x}} = 1
\tan x \csc x = \dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x} \cdot \dfrac{1}{\sin x} = \dfrac{1}{\cos x} = \sec x

answer.p: \cos t = \pm \sqrt{1-\sin^2 t}, ~\tan t = \dfrac{\pm \sin t}{\sqrt{1-\sin^2 t}}, ~\sec t = \dfrac{\pm 1}{\sqrt{1-\sin^2 t}}, ~\csc t = \dfrac{1}{\sin t}, ~ \cot t = \dfrac{\pm \sqrt{1-\sin^2 t}}{\sin t}

Show that if the angles of a triangle are A,~B, and C and the opposite sides are respectively a,~b, and c, then a \csc A = b \csc B = c \csc C

p.m: \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{a}{\sin A} \amp = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C}\\ a \cdot\dfrac{1}{\sin A} \amp = b \cdot \dfrac{1}{\sin B} = c \cdot \dfrac{1}{\sin C}\\ a \csc A \amp = b \csc B = c \csc C \end{aligned}
